channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: In Paris, the Seine Rises to Highest Level Since 1982
item.media:description: The banks of the Seine on Friday. The river reached its highest level since 1982.
item.media:credit: Pierre Terdjman for The New York Times
item.description: The river was expected to crest on Friday evening at around 21 feet, still far short of the 26.2 feet reached in 1910.
item.dc:creator: LILIA BLAISE and BENOÎT MORENNE

item.title: Why the Seine River Is Bursting Its Banks in Paris
item.media:description: Railways tracks were flooded near the Eiffel Tower on Friday after the rain-swollen Seine reached its highest level in three decades.
item.description: Not only has the Paris region been inundated by rain, but dams upstream were already near capacity.
item.dc:creator: DAPHNÉ ANGLÈS

item.title: Crowds Are Out, Crates Are In as Louvre Takes Flood Precautions
item.media:description: Artworks were packed to be moved from the Louvre Museum’s storeroom to the exhibition halls, where they would be less vulnerable to rising flood waters.
item.description: Rooms packed with Renaissance masterpieces like the “Mona Lisa” were eerily empty on Friday, while others were filled with works moved to higher ground.
item.dc:creator: LILIA BLAISE

item.title: Scapegoat or Spy? Vatican Consultant Commands Attention at Leaks Trial
item.media:description: Francesca Immacolata Chaouqui is accused of leaking confidential Vatican documents to two journalists.
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.description: A hero to some and a villain to others, Francesca Immacolata Chaouqui stands accused with two others of leaking confidential documents to two journalists.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Moldova Is Rattled as Washington Welcomes a Feared Tycoon
item.media:description: Riot police officers scuffled with protesters near the home of Vladimir Plahotniuc in Chisinau, Moldova, in April.
item.description: Vlad Plahotniuc is so toxic even his political friends usually try to keep their distance in public, but a State Department official met with him.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Okinawa Murder Case Heightens Outcry Over U.S. Military’s Presence
item.media:description: A moment of prayer where the body of a 20-year-old woman was found on Okinawa last month.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Okinawans have long complained of violence, noise and other problems associated with American bases. Now the bases’ very existence is drawing a backlash.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Thousands Rally in Hong Kong to Mark Tiananmen Anniversary
item.description: People gathered to do what those across the border in mainland China could not: mark the bloody crackdown on pro-democracy protesters in Beijing.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE and ALAN WONG

item.title: Tiger Sanctuary in Thailand Closes Amid Accusations of Wildlife Trafficking
item.description: Conservationists had long believed that the zoo, run by Buddhist monks, was a front for illegal trafficking in tiger parts.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Iraqi Army Seen as Ill Equipped to Retake Mosul From ISIS, Despite U.S. Aid
item.description: The Iraqis are having trouble moving supplies to their troops on battlefields, and a planned offensive against the Islamic State’s stronghold will probably have to wait.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Palestinians Elect a New President (on a Reality TV Show)
item.media:description: Security guards surrounded Waad Qannam, center with red tie, after he was announced as the show’s winner on Thursday.
item.description: “The President,” a reality show, allowed Palestinians to choose a leader, which they have not had the chance to do in more than a decade.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Trying to Fill Void, France Holds Talks on Mideast Peace Process
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry, center, greeted Borge Brende, the foreign minister of Norway, on Friday in Paris at talks on the Middle East peace process. Diplomats from 29 countries attended.
item.description: With tensions flaring between the Israelis and the Palestinians, France decided to propose a new process.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Iran’s Supreme Leader on America: Don’t Trust, Don’t Cooperate
item.description: A nationally televised speech by Ayatollah Ali Khamenei seemed to signal that Iran’s senior leadership would not allow any easing of hostility toward the United States.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: 24 Killed as Armed Protesters Clash With the Police in India
item.media:description: Fire engulfed buildings in Jawahar Bagh park in Mathura, India, that were used by a sect that fired on the police who were trying to evict them. At least 24 people were killed.
item.description: The violence, which left two top police officials dead and 23 officers wounded, occurred when authorities tried to evict the sect from a park in Mathura, India.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: U.S. Sanctions Expected to Hit Small Banks’ Business With North Korea
item.media:description: Chinese guards at the North Korean Embassy in Beijing. The United States Treasury Department has designated North Korea as a “primary money-laundering concern.”
item.description: The Chinese banks most affected by the sanctions on Pyongyang will be regional ones that facilitate the bulk of North Korea’s business in China.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: The Saturday Profile: With Views From the Inside, an Activist Challenges Vietnam’s Rulers
item.media:description: “If the authorities were smart, they would know that the protesters don’t want to overthrow them,but want to negotiate to change the policies.” NGUYEN QUANG A
item.media:credit: Hoang Dinh Nam/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Nguyen Quang A, an activist blocked from meeting with President Obama, says the Communist Party sometimes needs coaxing, and sometimes confrontation.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Migrant Boat Capsizes off Crete, Killing at Least 4
item.media:description: The body of a migrant washed up on a beach in Zuwarah, Libya, on Thursday.
item.description: About 340 refugees were rescued and a search was underway after the vessel, which may have held 700 people, overturned en route to Italy from Egypt.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Sinosphere: Remembering Tiananmen in Hong Kong, but Not Without Divisions
item.media:description: Lee Cheuk-yan, a member of the Legislative Council from the Labor Party and former chairman of the Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements of China, at the Legislative Council.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: For years, activists, student leaders and politicians gathered to declare solidarity in a continuing struggle for political change in China. This year is different.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG
item.category: Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements of China

item.title: Sinosphere: Getting Hitched in Beijing? Try to Look the Part, Please
item.media:description: A couple kissing at a marriage registry office in Beijing on Valentine’s Day.
item.description: The authorities in Beijing have determined that many couples showing up to register their marriages are just too casual.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Sinosphere: China’s Internet Speed Ranks 91st in the World
item.media:description: A woman on her phone in Pingyao, China. About half of the Chinese population is online, and 90 percent gain access to the internet via their phones.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: While trying to emphasize China’s connectivity, a report by a state newspaper acknowledged the creeping pace of connections in the country.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Japanese Boy, 7, Left on Mountain by Parents Is Found Alive
item.media:description: Yamato Tanooka in an undated photo.
item.media:credit: Jiji Press, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Missing for nearly a week, the boy was found in a cabin on a remote military base exhausted but apparently uninjured.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: Mohammed Abdelaziz, Advocate of an Independent Western Sahara, Dies at 68
item.media:description: Mohammed Abdelaziz in 2014. He was the leader of the Polisario Front in Western Sahara.
item.description: The Polisario Front, led for four decades by Mr. Abdelaziz, has tried to establish a sovereign state for the disputed region’s Berber tribesmen.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Brazil’s Soccer Prowess Has Been Consumed by Years of Neglect
item.media:description: Brazil was defeated by Paraguay in the quarterfinals of the 2015 Copa América.
item.description: As the Copa América Centenario kicks off this weekend and the Rio Olympics loom later this summer, Brazil’s national team is a shadow of its past.
item.dc:creator: EWAN MacKENNA

item.title: What in the World: When West Africans Dress, the Fabric Is the Message
item.media:description: The designs on wax print fabric worn by West African women can be very personal.
item.description: The bold patterns and images on wax print cotton cloth that many women wear may celebrate pop culture, religion, politics or social mores.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: What in the World: In Istanbul’s Taxis, Buckling Up Is an Insult
item.description: What’s the matter, don’t you trust my driving? You must be from out of town. (And, please, pay no attention to the speedometer.)
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: What in the World: The Y’s and Wherefores of How Cubans Name Their Children
item.description: Many born during the Cold War were given first names beginning with Y. Experts differ as to whether it was in tribute to the Soviet Union, or in rebellion.
item.dc:creator: ELI ROSENBERG

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Meet Sultana, the Taliban’s Worst Fear
item.media:description: Sultana pursued an education from inside her home in Afghanistan after the Taliban threatened to douse her with acid if she went back to school. Because of the danger to her and a photographer if she was visited there, her picture was taken via Skype.
item.media:credit: Andrew Quilty for The New York Times
item.description: An Afghan girl’s hunger for knowledge is stronger than the threat of an acid attack.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS KRISTOF

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The Timeless Temptation of Despots
item.description: Populists may play the system to gain power, but if they continue to undermine it, they will either destroy their nation, or it will destroy them.
item.dc:creator: NIKOS KONSTANDARAS
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: If the Trans-Pacific Partnership Crumbles, China Wins
item.description: Congress should ratify the Trans-Pacific Partnership. Its failure would be a big victory for China.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Iran’s Ruhollah Khomeini, a Man Who Shook the World
item.description: Mourning Ruhollah Khomeini, the founder of the Islamic republic, required every Iranian’s complete attention.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: With Obama in Japan, and a Puppy in Brooklyn
item.media:description: On the way to Hiroshima Peace Park to interview people gathered for President Obama’s visit, I cut through a shopping mall and saw this guy wearing a Times T-shirt. Of course we needed a picture.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Our soon-to-be Tokyo bureau chief learns to love Snapchat.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Have You Voted for a Far-Right Party in Europe? Share Your Thoughts
item.media:description: Supporters of the far-right Freedom Party at a rally in Vienna last month.
item.description: The Times is collecting the personal experiences of voters who have backed those groups. Whom did you support? What motivated you?
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
